metadata.title: A/B Testing Email Campaigns: What You Need to Know
metadata.description: A/B testing your emails is a critical part of giving your campaigns the best chance of producing results. This Guide shows you what you need to know.

sections: Newsletter subject lines are the first point of contact between you and the reader. They can make or break every issue of the newsletter — and, by extension, the newsletter itself.
It's crucial that you understand and get good at writing subject lines that matter to and resonate with your audience.
So, what makes a good subject line?
Sorry for the less than useful, but sadly it's clear that something that's a pretty sure fire success for one group of people won't work for another, as they'll see it irritating or “clickbaity”.

Grabbing a guide to great email subject headlines from the internet is something of a gamble. If you find one that happens to match the instincts of your target audince — then great. But otherwise, you're just trying off-the-shelf solutions that are likely to harm your open rates.

That's not to say that there aren't some more general rules we can explore. In the end though, it's going to come down to experimentation and testing within these guidlines. We'll look at testing later on in this page, and return to it in the analytics section.
Email, at its best, is a very personal medium. Things that make the newsletter sound personal tend to work well. Use of “you” when you can work it into the subject line can be effective.

In essence, this allows you to segment your newsletter audience, and send one of them a newsletter with, say, a more casual subject line, and the other a more business-like headline. You can then compare open rates between the two, and use that to help refine your sense of the sorts of subject line that work for you audience.

It's the single most useful tool you use to helop refine your understanding of your audience and what works for them, which is why it baffles me that it's available on so many marketing automation platforms, but not editorial newsletter ones.
That said, there are a few caveats worth noting:
The tool works better with larger groups rather than small ones, as that reduces oddities thrown up by an uneven spread of the types of subscriber in each group.
Some things are easier to A/B test that others (see below).
A/B testing can be risky — if you're not cautious in your tests, you run the risk of annoying one of the test groups and losing subscribers as a result.
— measured through open rates. You can vary the complete subject line, the word order of the subject line, its length, its tone and so on.

— what style of intro works best for your audience? Look at the options we discussed in the structure section, and consider runing tests. You'll probably measure through aggregate click-through rates or by running long-term tests, with two separate but consistent segments, and see how open rates shift over time.

— Do your readers prefer image-rich emails, or do they like to get down to basics with the text? You'll probably measure through aggregate click-through rates or by running long-term tests, with two separate but consistent segments, and see how open rates shift over time.

— Measured through open rates and click-through rates. Getting timing right for newsletters can be critical. If you have two theories about the best time to send, then split your audience, and test which time slot gets the better open and click-through rates.

These are tests that you need to run over longer periods of time (weeks to months), and which carry a greater element of risk. Why risk? You are likely to lose some subscribers from the group which has the less successful alternative.
Generally, I advise sticking to set periods for most editorial testing — but not for these sorts of newsletter testing.
As soon as a clear pattern emerges, end the test, and standardise on the more popular option.
